name: Cyberspace is for Pawn v1.4
description:
Evolution of my Ci4P deck, published back before Deep Red enabled the whole thing. Owes the inclusion of Sheherazade to db0 and the Street Chess deck from the Netrunomicon guys.

Tends to be event heavy, as my thinking is that all this extra draw for Exile's ability needs to draw /something/ and yet the Pawn cycle needs successful runs to fuel it. Thus Run events make sense to include, which is why Indexing and The Maker's Eye, as well as Stimhack appear in the list. Escher can win games, and if pressed you can reconfigure the Ice array to place Ice hosting the Pawns at the bottom of servers (one shot, but a small acceleration here) before resolving the successful run clauses on Pawns. Also helps to make R&D more vulnerable, of course.

This version feels the lack of Levy AR Lab Access, but the slots for it just didn't feel available. Faerie is an awesome breaker for Exile allowing safe face-checking as well as fuelling his ability.

There's a tension with only so much search as to use it to tutor for the combo elements or to actually assemble the breaker suite. Gut feel is probably the best guide here, after playing a few games.

When the combo comes together, it is a thing of beauty. ;-)

name: The Valley of Evil v2.0
description:
Jinteki RP - lock deck under development (this is an historical version circa Creation and Control).

Uses Ruhr Valley to try to lock the Runner out of the Agenda server long enough to score Agenda. Nisei Mk II can end runs (after they waste credits down that server). False Lead also terminates the option to attack the Ruhr server.

Ice mix here is probably inadequate for the job, and I'm not sure what I was thinking w.r.t. Cell Portal?!

name: The Valley of Evil v2.0.2
description:
Historical posting: revised version of "Valley of Evil v2.0" - still in the CnC era, before Spin cycle.

Dropped the Chum, and Cell Portal, in favour of better Ice for the lock concept. Archer went out when the number of 3/1 Agenda dropped and only False Lead remained (keeping them for the lock function rather than rezzing Archer). Snowflake comes in to fill the rez-cost slot that Chum fell out of. Akitaro and Chimera are just funny together if the Runner is trying to drain your credits by running it.

Hourglass is strong over HQ or Archives when it matters that the Runner loses the rest of the turn, save it for a face-check surprise if possible, for when the Runner makes a milk run to load Datasucker tokens, plays Dirty Laundry, etc. Viper can eat up valuable clicks, and is otherwise costly to break; it is also not click breakable like Eli 1.0 which was in the deck before. Cell Portal did not perform, despite the attraction of having it at the bottom of the Ruhr Valley server, and looping the Runner to drain credits (if they have to jack out that saves you a Nisei Mk II agenda counter).

Agenda was re-considered in light of my thinking in this article, trying to minimise the investment of actions required to win by slow advancing Agenda, which is the main path to victory here. The third False Lead was a tough inclusion, but its ability to enable the Ruhr Valley lock after the Runner makes a central run on their first click is very important to have available.

name: Femme Fatale / Atman Recursion III
description:
Driving concept is Femme Fatale Heap/board Recursion to re-set targets and power counters to face any ice. Modded and test run speed up the femme fatale set up and Bishop/Datasucker give extra reach for atman.

Chaos Theory instead of Exile for more consistency and draw Efficency.

name: True Colors Media Blitz
description:
An update/remake of my older deck revisited with the newer card pool.

R&D lock is a common threat for this deck, hudson breaks this up pretty good, and he's cheap (INF and cost).

The rest is standard draw+credits. Don't blow all your money at once, hovering around 2-3 credits is fine, with SfSS and GLC and other bursty econ.

The new burst econ in sweeps week should really break this open on the sansan end of things, whereas before sansan was an "if you're lucky" type situation.

name: NBN Blitzkrieg
description: My take on x3r0h0urs media blitz. Possible changes: Ice Wall vs Paper Wall - sometimes the 1 cred to rez matters. TGTBT vs Profiteering - I like TGTBT for making them waste clicks and possibly fake a tag&bag deck. Chimera vs ? - Reina hurts.

name: Supermodernism Shutdown

Won the Store Championship @Berkeley

Deck by Martin Presley.

name: Credits Shutdown
description: Main play is to shutdown whole deck and go for the Jackson Howard + Accelerated Diagnostics combo. Make the runner poor and go for the combo with SEA Source + Scorched + Scorched. The runner is tagged? Triple scorched. He stole a 3pt agenda? Triple Counterstrike Punishment. You always have the option to creat a big remote wall and score agendas as well.

name: The Valley of Evil v2.1
description:
Updated version of "Valley of Evil v2.0.2“, taking on board Celebrity Gift, Unorthodox Predictions and Sundew. Sundew is a potential monster for RP, and there's been few occasions where I've not been prepared to get the full payout from Gift.

Lack of any Ambush Assets is a possible weakness for this iteration, though one Snare! seems hardly worth it. With the influence count so high it's hard to see where to include Jackson Howard; this deck, unlike PE, wants to stop the Runner if it can. Archer gets a guernsey again with the inclusion of Unorthodox Predictions, which timed right can chain in another Agenda, but with three-odd turns of advancing you both need to shift to credit consolidation and shoring up defences after that. UP can become Archer fodder after it's done its job, though.

Ideally you're able to score one of the Priority Requisitions, along with a two points Agenda to head to match point, or set up a couple of 3/1st to establish the lock in phase three of the game, negating the Runner's advantage in that stage of the game.
